Project Modules (PyQt5 Path)

submission.part1_oop

Core OOP models and utilities for a simple school management system.

This module defines the domain objects (Person, Student, Instructor, Course) and helpers to validate input, serialize/deserialize data, and export reports to CSV and plain-text “pretty” tables.

class submission.part1_oop.Course(course_id: str, course_name: str, instructor: ~submission.part1_oop.Instructor | None = None, enrolled_students: ~typing.List[~submission.part1_oop.Student] = <factory>)[source]

Bases: object

A course offering with an optional instructor and enrolled students.

Parameters:

  • course_id (str) – Unique identifier for the course (e.g., CS101).

  • course_name (str) – Human-readable course name (e.g., Intro to CS).

  • instructor (Instructor | None) – The assigned instructor, if any.

  • enrolled_students (list[Student]) – Students currently enrolled in the course.

Enroll a student in this course (idempotent).

If the student is already enrolled, nothing happens.

Parameters:

submission.part1_oop.export_csv(students: List[Student], instructors: List[Instructor], courses: List[Course], folder: str) → None[source]

Export students, instructors, and courses to CSV and pretty text files.

This creates three CSV files inside folder:

  • students.csv basic student info and a ;-separated list of course IDs.

  • instructors.csv instructor info and assigned course IDs.

  • courses.csv course details, instructor ID (or -), and enrolled student IDs.

It also writes plain-text tables into folder/pretty_tables using write_pretty_table() for quick inspection in a terminal.

Parameters:

  • students (list[Student]) – Students to export.

  • instructors (list[Instructor]) – Instructors to export.

  • courses (list[Course]) – Courses to export.

  • folder (str) – Destination directory (created if it does not exist).

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

submission.part1_oop.from_json(path: str) → Dict[str, List][source]

Load students, instructors, and courses from a JSON export.

This reconstructs objects and their relationships:

  • Instructors are created first and mapped by instructor_id.

  • Students are created and mapped by student_id.

  • Courses are created, then linked to their instructor and enrolled students.

  • Student registered_courses is synchronized from both directions (student→course and course→student).

Parameters:

path (str) – Path to a JSON file previously created by to_json().

Returns:

A dict with keys 'students', 'instructors', 'courses'.

Return type:

dict[str, list]

submission.part1_oop.is_valid_age(age: int | str) → bool[source]

Return True if age can be parsed as a non-negative integer.

Parameters:

age (int | str) – Age value or string representation (e.g., 18 or "18").

Returns:

True for age >= 0, otherwise False (including parse errors).

Return type:

bool

submission.part1_oop.is_valid_email(email: str) → bool[source]

Return True if the string looks like a valid email address.

A simple regex is used to catch the most common mistakes (missing @, spaces, no TLD, …). It is not meant to be 100% RFC-compliant.

Parameters:

email (str) – Email address to check.

Returns:

True if the email matches EMAIL_RE, otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

submission.part1_oop.to_json(students: List[Student], instructors: List[Instructor], courses: List[Course], path: str) → None[source]

Serialize the current in-memory model to a JSON file.

Students and instructors are stored with their basic fields. Course relationships are flattened to IDs to avoid recursion:

  • Each student stores a list of course IDs (registered_courses).

  • Each instructor stores a list of course IDs (assigned_courses).

  • Each course stores its instructor_id (or null) and a list of enrolled student IDs.

Parameters:

  • students (list[Student]) – All students to include in the export.

  • instructors (list[Instructor]) – All instructors to include in the export.

  • courses (list[Course]) – All courses to include in the export.

  • path (str) – Destination JSON file path.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

submission.part1_oop.write_pretty_table(headers: List[str], rows: List[List[Any]], path: str) → None[source]

Write a fixed-width plain-text table to a file.

Columns are sized to the widest value in each column so the result is easy to read in any text editor. The parent directory is created if needed.

Parameters:

  • headers (list[str]) – Column headings, one per column.

  • rows (list[list[Any]]) – Table rows; each row is a list with the same length as headers.

  • path (str) – Destination file path for the generated table (.txt recommended).

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

submission.part3_pyqt5

PyQt5 GUI for a simple school management system.

This module implements a desktop UI to manage students, instructors, and courses. It supports adding/updating/deleting records, assigning instructors, registering students into courses, simple search, and exporting data to JSON, CSV, and plain-text “pretty” tables.

class submission.part3_pyqt5.Main(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]

Bases: QMainWindow

Main application window with Students/Instructors/Courses tabs.

Initialize the main window and populate initial UI state.

Sets title/size, builds widgets and layouts, and refreshes all tables/ dropdowns to reflect the current in-memory DATA store.

Add or update a course from the form fields.

Requires a course ID and name. Updates the in-memory DATA store and refreshes the UI.

add_instructor()[source]

Add or update an instructor from the form fields.

Performs required-field checks, email validation, and non-negative age validation. Updates the in-memory DATA store and refreshes the UI.

add_student()[source]

Add or update a student from the form fields.

Performs required-field checks, email validation, and non-negative age validation. Updates the in-memory DATA store and refreshes the UI.

Assign the selected instructor to the selected course.

Delete the currently selected row of the given table.

Adjusts related data to keep the in-memory model consistent and then refreshes the affected tables and dropdowns.

Parameters:

  • table (QtWidgets.QTableWidget) – Source table (students, instructors, or courses table).

  • kind (str) – One of 'student', 'instructor', or 'course'.

Returns:

export_csvs()[source]

Export CSV files and pretty text tables to a folder.

Creates: - students.csv with ID, name, age, email, courses - instructors.csv with ID, name, age, email - courses.csv with course ID, name, instructor ID, students

Also writes fixed-width text tables in pretty_tables for quick viewing.

Register the selected student into the selected course.

submission.part3_pyqt5.write_pretty_table(headers, rows, path)[source]

Write a fixed-width plain-text table to path.

Columns are sized to the widest value so the output lines up in any text editor or terminal. The destination directory is created if needed.

Parameters:

  • rows (list[list[object]]) – Table rows; each row is a list of values matching headers length.

  • path (str) – Destination file path for the generated table (.txt recommended).

Returns:

submission.part4_database

School database: SQLite backend + a tiny Tkinter app.

This module contains two parts:

  • Database layer (SQLite): tables for students, instructors, courses, and registrations, with foreign keys turned on. You will find small helper functions for the usual CRUD actions (create/read/update/delete), plus utilities to export CSV files and to make timestamped database backups.

  • Desktop UI (Tkinter): a simple, tabbed window (App) that lets you add people and courses, assign instructors, register students, and run the export/backup tools—without touching SQL.

Why this exists: its a compact example of how to wire a GUI to a real database. The focus is on clarity: straightforward schema, clean functions, and a minimal interface that shows the full round-trip from UI → database → files.

class submission.part4_database.App(root)[source]

Bases: object

Minimal Tkinter application exposing CRUD and export actions.
